Package com.rubynaxela.kyanite.graphics

Class VertexArray

java.lang.Object
com.rubynaxela.kyanite.graphics.BasicTransformable
com.rubynaxela.kyanite.graphics.VertexArray
All Implemented Interfaces:
BoundsObject, Drawable, Transformable, Serializable, Iterable<Vertex>, Collection<Vertex>, List<Vertex>, org.jsfml.graphics.Drawable
public class VertexArray extends BasicTransformable implements List<Vertex>, Serializable, Drawable, BoundsObject
Defines a drawable set of one or multiple 2D primitives.
See Also:
  • Serialized Form

      public Color getFillColor()
      Gets the vertex array's current fill color. This method does not take color changes made manually to the individual vertices into account, but rather only returns the color set by the setFillColor(com.rubynaxela.kyanite.graphics.Color) method.

    • setFillColor

      public void setFillColor(@NotNull @NotNull Color color)
      Sets the fill color of the vertex array by applying the color to every vertex. The default color is Colors.WHITE.
      Parameters:
      color - the new fill color of the shape, or Colors.TRANSPARENT to indicate that the shape should not be filled

    • toArray

      @NotNull public @NotNull Object @NotNull [] toArray()
      Returns an array containing all of the elements in this VertexArray in proper sequence (from first to last vertex). The returned array will be "safe" in that no references to it are maintained by this VertexArray. (In other words, this method must allocate a new array). The caller is thus free to modify the returned array. This method acts as bridge between array-based and collection-based APIs.
      Specified by:
      toArray in interface Collection<Vertex>
      Specified by:
      toArray in interface List<Vertex>
      Returns:
      an array containing all of the elements in this list in proper sequence

    • toArray

      @NotNull public <T> @NotNull T @NotNull [] toArray(@NotNull @NotNull T @NotNull [] a)
      Returns an array containing all of the elements in this VertexArray in proper sequence (from first to last vertex); the runtime type of the returned array is that of the specified array. If the VertexArray fits in the specified array, it is returned therein. Otherwise, a new array is allocated with the runtime type of the specified array and the size of this VertexArray. If the VertexArray fits in the specified array with room to spare (i.e. the array has more elements than the VertexArray), the vertex in the array immediately following the end of the collection is set to null. (This is useful in determining the length of the list only if the caller knows that the list does not contain any null elements.)
      Specified by:
      toArray in interface Collection<Vertex>
      Specified by:
      toArray in interface List<Vertex>
      Parameters:
      a - the array into which the vertices of the VertexArray are to be stored, if it is big enough; otherwise, a new array of the same runtime type is allocated for this purpose
      Returns:
      an array containing the vertices of the VertexArray
      Throws:
      ArrayStoreException - if the runtime type of the specified array is not a supertype of Vertex
      NullPointerException - if the specified array is null

    • remove

      public boolean remove(Object vertex)
      Removes the first occurrence of the specified vertex from this VertexArray, if it is present. If the VertexArray does not contain the element, it is unchanged. More formally, removes the vertex with the lowest index i such that Objects.equals(vertex, get(i)) (if such an element exists). Returns true if this VertexArray contained the specified element (or equivalently, if this VertexArray changed as a result of the call).
      Specified by:
      remove in interface Collection<Vertex>
      Specified by:
      remove in interface List<Vertex>
      Parameters:
      vertex - vertex to be removed from this VertexArray, if present
      Returns:
      true if this list contained the specified element

    • addAll

      public boolean addAll(@NotNull @NotNull Collection<? extends Vertex> c)
      Appends all of the vertices in the specified collection to the end of this VertexArray, in the order that they are returned by the specified collection's Iterator. The behavior of this operation is undefined if the specified collection is modified while the operation is in progress. (This implies that the behavior of this call is undefined if the specified collection is this VertexArray, and this VertexArray is nonempty.)
      Specified by:
      addAll in interface Collection<Vertex>
      Specified by:
      addAll in interface List<Vertex>
      Parameters:
      c - collection containing vertices to be added to this VertexArray
      Returns:
      true if this VertexArray changed as a result of the call, false otherwise
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the specified collection is null

    • addAll

      public boolean addAll(int index, @NotNull @NotNull Collection<? extends Vertex> c)
      Inserts all of the vertices in the specified collection into this VertexArray, starting at the specified position. Shifts the vertex currently at that position (if any) and any subsequent vertex to the right (increases their indices). The new vertices will appear in the VertexArray in the order that they are returned by the specified collection's Iterator.
      Specified by:
      addAll in interface List<Vertex>
      Parameters:
      index - index at which to insert the first vertex from the specified collection
      c - collection containing vertices to be added to this VertexArray
      Returns:
      true if this VertexArray changed as a result of the call, false otherwise
      Throws:
      IndexOutOfBoundsException
      NullPointerException - if the specified collection is null

    • listIterator

      @NotNull public @NotNull ListIterator<Vertex> listIterator()
      Returns a list iterator over the vertices in this VertexArray (in proper sequence). The returned list iterator is fail-fast.

    • listIterator

      @NotNull public @NotNull ListIterator<Vertex> listIterator(int index)
      Returns a list iterator over the elements in this VertexArray (in proper sequence), starting at the specified position in the VertexArray. The specified index indicates the first element that would be returned by an initial call to next. An initial call to previous would return the element with the specified index minus one. The returned list iterator is fail-fast.
      Specified by:
      listIterator in interface List<Vertex>
      Parameters:
      index - the starting position of the iterator
      Throws:
      IndexOutOfBoundsException

    • subList

      @NotNull public @NotNull VertexArray subList(int fromIndex, int toIndex)
      Returns a view of the portion of this VertexArray between the specified fromIndex, inclusive, and toIndex, exclusive. (If fromIndex and toIndex are equal, the returned VertexArray is empty.) The returned VertexArray is backed by this VertexArray, so non-structural changes in the returned VertexArray are reflected in this VertexArray, and vice-versa. The returned VertexArray supports all of the optional list operations. This method eliminates the need for explicit range operations (of the sort that commonly exist for arrays). Any operation that expects a list can be used as a range operation by passing a subList view instead of a whole VertexArray. For example, the following idiom removes a range of elements from a VertexArray: 
            array.subList(from, to).clear();
      Similar idioms may be constructed for indexOf(Object) and lastIndexOf(Object), and all of the algorithms in the Collections class can be applied to a subList. The semantics of the VertexArray returned by this method become undefined if the backing VertexArray (i.e. this VertexArray) is structurally modified in any way other than via the returned VertexArray. (Structural modifications are those that change the size of this list, or otherwise perturb it in such a fashion that iterations in progress may yield incorrect results.)
      Specified by:
      subList in interface List<Vertex>
      Throws:
      IndexOutOfBoundsException
      IllegalArgumentException
